greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Count up from -n to n for n = 0, 1, 2, ... .
comment: This sequence contains every integer infinitely often, hence all integer sequences are subsequences.

Indeed, if all terms (a(n),a(n+1)) such that a(n+1) does NOT equal a(n)+1 (<=> a(n+1) < a(n)) are deleted, the same sequence is recovered again. See A253580 for an "opposite" yet similar "fractal tree" construction. - _M. F. Hasler_, Jan 04 2015
reference: Miklós Laczkovich, Conjecture and Proof, TypoTex, Budapest, 1998. See Chapter 10.
link: Reinhard Zumkeller, Rows n=0..100 of triangle, flattened
Boris Putievskiy, Transformations [of] Integer Sequences And Pairing Functions arXiv:1212.2732 [math.CO], 2012.
formula: a(n) = n - t*t - t - 1, where t = floor(sqrt(n-1)). - _Boris Putievskiy_, Jan 28 2013
G.f.: x/(x-1)^2 + 1/(x-1)*sum(k >= 1, 2*k*x^(k^2)).  The series is related to Jacobi theta functions. - _Robert Israel_, Jan 05 2015
example: The sequence of fractions A196199/A004737 = 0/1, -1/1, 0/2, 1/1, -2/1, -1/2, 0/3, 1/2, 2/1, -3/1, -2/2, -1/3, 0/4, 1/3, 2/2, 3/1, -4/4. -3/2, ... contains every rational number (infinitely often) [Laczkovich]. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Oct 09 2013
maple: # Alternatively, as a table with rows -n<=k<=n (compare A257564):
seq(print(seq(T(n, k), k=-n..n)), n=0..6); # _Peter Luschny_, May 28 2015
xref: Cf. absolute values A053615, A002262, A002260, row lengths A005408, row sums A000004, A071797.
results.author: _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Sep 29 2011
